cons: Work is NOT enough and never will be... till the time you learn how to get credit for it. And even in cons. I got something to learn so that is another reason to work at COLLABERA :)
story: When I joined Collabera, someone told me in my induction (I think that was Sumeet Pankajakshan or Ayush Vyas) that all 19 folks in that batch should understand one thing that if you're here (Joining Collabera) then there are only two possibilities either Collabera is the best option you've got or you do not have any other option... For me the both of them were true and the best part is that Collabera (People) almost never let me feel either of it... I'd say this mattered most to me in my 8 years journey with Collabera and it is something that defines Collabera Culture at its BEST.

story: We had few niche requirements coming our way from our client. Most of the competitors gave up knowing the complexity of hiring process and also difficulty in finding niche resources. Partnership between me and sales together helped to crack the deal and opened the doors to directly interact with with Director of that specific LOB. We are the top and only vendor that comes to their mind when they have to fill such difficult requirements now and we finally built the entire team for them. Game changer for us was the quality of the resumes Sourced and shared that helped the sales to be confident enough  to present in front of the client and get the deal our way!! We displayed all our Collabera’s core values during the entire transactions thus leaving our marks at the client side

pros: Since Collabera intends to use technology to drive its growth, there would be good opportunities for developers.
cons: Since Collabera is not primarily a technology company, sometimes expectations by business people might be little unrealistic. Also, it might be a bit difficult to explain to business leaders why some development projects, change requests might take time. Its difficult for business people to understand that due to intangible nature of the technology work, estimation might not be accurate and there can be delays, and that delays are not uncommon. Technology processes are not in place, so there is ad hoc way of doing things which might speed things up a little. However its not desirable in the long run, if Collabera truly aims to be a company where technology is supposed to be driving factor, instead of just being enabler of business. Unrealistic deadlines put pressure on developers and there is always danger that quality will suffer.

pros: Collabera's female friendly environment, all the 5 cultural values really resonates in my personal life
cons: Our working hours compared to the other industry standards and the package we offer sometimes makes difficult to tap the potential candidates our competitors
story: I faced the first professional challenge for one of my hiring projects for a key customer account. The candidate that had the right skill set-aligned with the client requirement was unwilling to engage with Collabera due to some prior bad-experience. One of the key personal traits that helped me to resolve the issue was my empathetic behavior along with imbibing the Collabera's passion to serve its clients & employees. I decided to engage with the candidate with an approach of listening and understanding the root cause. Based on the discussion, it was clear that the reason of the unhappiness was the absence of feedback on the various applications that the candidate has engaged with our company. On one hand I apologized for the earlier experiences and on the other hand promised her to provide a timely feedback. This helped to secure the candidate for my client and consequently to win business for Collabera. This incidence taught me a great lesson of my life that human are the key resources that defines the success or the failure of an organization hence being passionate in your responsibilities helps you breakthrough the toughest challenges

pros:
Collabera has a very engaging environment, never have I ever felt isolated or separated in any task or activity.
The work environment has a very coherent structure, with clearly defined roles that  prevents any kind of misunderstanding.
Here, talent is appreciated, hard work even more so, and your team quickly becomes part of your family.
cons:
Working in such a massive organization requires certain adjustments and sacrifices.
Night shift requires a decent acclimatization period.
story:
After working with an established team for 10 months, I was asked if I would like to make a move to one of the newer teams.
Initially, I was concerned, not only about the transition, but whether I would be able to show the same level of productivity in the new team.
I discussed with my lead, Manager and teammates and decided to make the JUMP. 
Suffice to say, the success I have experienced made me realize that I was given a chance not only to move out of my comfort zone, but also to maximize my potential by being a part of an emerging venture.

cons: Staffing involves a lot of work and moving parts. You have to deal with the people-factor, which can mean you do everything right and something out of your control can derail a sale/hire/start. pros:
Work culture at Collabera. A good balance between work and leisure. Coordination among employees is appreciable. Everyone has sharing and caring attitude. Everyone is equally respected irrespective of whether he or she is fresher, experienced, senior or at a junior level. 
Collabera's core value describes everything about how we work and cater to our consultants as well as clients. On the whole I find it a best organization to work for.
cons: There are many positive aspects of working in Collabera. But there are some negative points also which I think should be taken care of. But it is my perception which may or may not be true. Work hours are long which I think should be reduced a bit. I do not find any other negative aspect of working at Collabera.
story:
My managers supported me right from my induction phase till date they are supporting me a lot. They cared me and motivated me in every aspect. They showed me right path to succceed. I was initially stucked after my induction phase was over and was very much disappointed that I will not be able to work any more here as I lacked enough intellect to become a successful recruiter.
But my trainer motivated me and she worked with me for around two weeks continuously due to which finally I came on track and now enjoying my work whole heartidly.

pros: The people, everyone is so nice - super energetic, very very hard working and HONEST. When you do well, you will know it and when you mess up, you will know it but it will always come with a learning lesson.
cons: Internal systems are slow, the offshore IT team is quick to say they can not do things or will argue with you that you did something incorrectly - and once you prove them wrong they do not apologize. We have to escalate things a lot but once you do it gets done.
story: I just love how everything is a celebration. Get a hire? Celebration? Get engaged - celebration, buy your first nice purse or dress shoe or watch - everyone celebrates. No matter how small or large (inside of work or an event outside of work) there is such a sense of community. This job is not easy. Its just not. There are days when I am like what the heck just happened, but you have people constantly supporting you and 'hyping' you up - even if you did make a mistake someone in your office will be there to try and make you feel better and do it differently next time.

pros: Collabera is one of the best company when it comes to working culture. Great working atmosphere with helpful people. Never felt that people here are stranger to me. Everyone is treated equally and every good work which is done by any of us is appreciated by the management. Incentive plans are far better than other companies.
cons: Obviously the first thing which will come in our mind is night shift. Working in night is not everyone's cup of tea. Just need some time to adjust, not really a big Con i would say. Second is the working hours. Sometimes or say many times we work more than the actual working hours. Little increment in the base salary would make it perfect place to work.
story: When I had my first submission, just a submission my lead motivated me and congratulated me for that, and this appreciation really meant to me as I was new in the team and that was my first day on floor. When I got my first hire, I was appreciated by my whole team, I would say it was whole floor. My work was acknowledged by my team and it was awesome for me. Team gathering for lunch or breakfast and the trips we have is something that we all appreciate.

pros:
Working at Collabera is an amazing experience. Being my first job, I have enjoyed every moment here at Collabera. The work culture at Collabera gives an experience of professionalism which is really important for someone who is beginning their professional journey. To sum it up in a few points, Collabera offer : 
-Excellent Work Culture
-Professionalism
-Continuous room for development
cons:
There are no downsides as such but yes there can be a few points where we can improve:
-More disciplined work schedule which can improve efficiency
-Employee Reward Structure
-Interaction between different departments
story:
The best story are the from the time when you struggle. So here is mine.
I had a rough patch in work where everything was going against me, the efforts were not giving the outcomes.
This was the time when I saw the support my managers and Collabera gave me. Their confidence in me gave a much needed support in not letting my moral down and eventually I was back on track in a short span of time.

pros:
Resources: we're one of the lucky companies to have the resources to send our employees to WFH fully equipped. 
Open door policy: everyone is always willing to help when a coworker is in need
The positive reinforcement: highlights, shoutouts, etc: definitely builds our confidence, motivation and the work hard play hard attitude
cons: Sometimes not everyone is on the same page, causing a domino effect on everyone else involved (AAMs-AM-Delivery). 80% of the time I feel there is more and more thrown at us/on our plates, making it a little overwhelming sometimes. Like priorities for HL's and metric expectations there, along with ref checks, along with inhouses, along with helping other ref checks, along with setting meetings etc etc. and Clique-iness/mutual respect when talking to coworkers, on and offshore
story: In the very beginning of my employment there was a candidate (Sr level) that was basically just a know-it-all and a little rude to me for not knowing the ins and outs of a certain database/platform. During phone screen with my AM, candidate had another comment and with no hesitation, my AM had my back professionally and reiterated to me that we would not move forward if I did not feel comfortable with this candidate. I think working in an environment where you know everyone has each others backs is so important!

pros:
'- From GCI to Collabera, for me it has always been first wife. Lot of arguments, logical/illogical but Mehul always forgave me. Rahul always there to guide me. Himanshu does understands my strength/weakness and knows how to get work done from me. CP is my Nemesis. Kapil one of the smart guy, who is my role model. Title does not motivate me but people does and these are few people who make a strong reason to work with Collabera.
- Collabera was there when I met with almost fatal road accident.
- People are treated as people by Collabera.
- Ample opportunity is given to new joiners to perform. 
- This is second recession that I am seeing with Collabera and we did not lay people off, at least in Baroda.
- It’s been 14 years, still feels like day one, however miss big time working with Mehul, Rahul and CP. 
- Sham, Hemin, HireMe...the down to earth people, for whom would do anything.
- I can go on, Collabera is the best place to work with.
cons:
'- If someone wants to resign, we make it too difficult for that person, not saying we should not try to save, but it gets too much.
-Feel a lot that,I am a slave to U.S. counter parts especially NAMs. They don't understand people challenges here in Baroda, have to obey them. Was thrown out of client coz of chemistry mismatch.
- I have clients who are a big time challenge to cater, but that is not taken into consideration during ratings and/or money. 
- I have overshot stretch target, but was paid for stretch money, when target missed was very less or nothing.
- We are or entering or entered in saturation phase, opportunities are drying up.
story:
'- Responsive beyond Imagination - CP even managing the day, he responds to my email even at middle of night(India). Rahul always responds to me in few hours.
- Play hard Work hard - CPL, CVPL, Navratri, Diwali, Christmas...biggest of all Blaze are true example of how we play hard. Got a bulk deal on Friday and people were there to work on Saturday to support it.

story: I love Collabera's culture from my office and I think all of us exemplify the mentality Collabrea tries to portray professionally. There are other offices (through stories I've heard) and people that have come in town from other offices that do not portray it correctly or professionally. For example, once we had somebody in town visiting from another office and we went to happy hour with said person. At the happy hour when I was moving into the sales roles she said "you need to make sure that you're portraying the idea of these managers potentially getting what they want from you, but never actually letting them. I once had a manager say he was going to leave his wife for me, now that was too far."

pros: Young culture (i.e. everyone is a similar age and can relate to a lot of shared life experiences), culture of growth depending on department, work perks such as PC, Top 30, Employee Appreciation Week, happy hours, spread milestones, etc
cons: sales is the only department that gets consistent public praise, while departments that are non "producers" do a TON of work without any recognition (i.e. L&D, CR, CRE, Ops, etc.); another con is the somewhat archaic culture of in-office work with little work-from-home flexibility, the fact that you must wear a suit to the office even if the city's client culture is more relaxed
story: The Top 30 trip - the best part was the recognition for our hard work and getting to truly "play hard" in Dubai and during Blaze. However, the con of the Top 30 trip was working in India. Why "treat" your Top 30 employees to a *full* week of working the night shift? It was a pleasure to meet my teammates overseas but it did not feel special or honorary that I had to work as a reward for my work. We were unable to do ANY sight-seeing or exploratory trips in India for that reason, which was a big bummer. I apologize if this makes me sound lazy, but I hope you can understand where I'm coming from. I would have loved the Top 30 trip to mirror PC - go to a gorgeous location, have an award ceremony, and relax the whole time.

pros:
'- I am very money motivated and like having the opportunity to earn bonuses for the hard work I put in. 

- I love most of the people I work with. 

- Opportunity for advancement.
cons:
'- Capped bonuses. 

- Level of professionalism going down. 

- Issues with open door policy and role outlines - escalation processes aren't clearly defined and job descriptions change often so there is always a ton of crossover and inconsistent direction from management.
story: Over the past few years I feel that our level of professionalism has significantly decreased making it easy for many of us to feel that we have aged out of the company. The AAM program feels more like a sorority than a professional development program and I think that much of this is our doing and not the AAMs fault. These recent grads take our lead and while I think it is so important to create a fairly fun, comfortable atmosphere where they feel inspired to grow, that line, in my opinion, has been crossed into an area where people really only come to work for the fun and friends. I saw an email just the other day where the interviewer said they "couldn't stop staring at [AAM candidate] during the interview because [she] is drop dead gorgeous." This email went out to the entire region announcing this person's hiring and welcoming her to the team. I love that we can have fun at work and truly do value that but I do also feel that it is important to remember that we are still in a professional environment.

pros: Collabera is a great place to work because of the culture embedded in each office that allow us to work together as a unit. After attending multiple training sessions and Governance calls, to me, one thing remains consistent - our passion to place candidates within our clients and our competitive nature. This allows us as individuals to grow as professionals and as people in general.
cons: Unfortunately, the turnover in my office in particular is a negative aspect of this job that I have experienced. It ties into my point about culture - we have to make sure that internally we are employing the right people to avoid constant attrition and knowledge transfer.
story: Rachel Gallo, and Account Manager in St. Louis with me, once worked on a position with a manager at Wells Fargo for over 6 months before filling it. This was due to not identifying quality talent, getting offers rejected by candidates, working within a tight budget and much more. Throughout those 6 months, Rachel did not give up and worked tirelessly to match the perfect candidate with a rather picky manager. This to me is a reflection of our values to be passionate to serve and disciplined to achieve excellence in execution

pros: Personally, I have got the best team to work with and it feels like a family. Apart from work relationship, we share personal connections as well and these people do not feel less than a family. I am so amazed and blessed to have this kind of family in my life. Thank you Collabera for giving me this opportunity to be here.
cons: Initially, the work pressure seemed high because I just got in from college. It really made me think if this is a place for me or if I can survive this pressure. The targets would sometimes make me go crazy.
story: Initially, it was very difficult for me to cope up with the pressure. But then I was aligned under Anshuman Singh and he is such an awesome person to work with. The healthy team environment that he created has me speechless. As a company the first thing should be a healthy work life environment and to help figure out the difficulties one is facing. The constant support that I receive from my manager and the team has really proved that Collabera is isn't just a name but also an example of how one can collaborate with each other and help each other grow. It's the best place to start a career if someone chooses to be in staffing.

pros: Being a part of a work in progress will one day be nice - when we see progress happening.
cons: Commission issues constantly, confusing systems that rarely work, treated like a number by upper level Management. Heavy male leadership. Upper level managements goals are the only ones that matter - not considering the health and safety of their employees. When our leading competition is letting their Employees work from home and have completely revolutionized the way they treat their employees it's embarrassing to see how little progress we have made.
story: When people say they love the culture of Collabera it's because they love their offices. The overall company culture is not unified at all. The cultures of offshore and onshore and vastly different and it's frustrating for both sides. We need to find a way to bridge the gap between our on and off shore teams. We need to consolidate back office teams so employees understand where to go for things and what people do. There are too many pockets of people that pop into situations that I have no idea who they are.  I know people are excited about the bigger picture and the larger goal - but we need to fix what's broken right now.

pros: Lots of young people, not a super stressful job, get lots of experience in different aspects of sales industry and other industries (example: learning more about the clients we work with)
cons: The culture sucks. People talk about each other all the time and I’ve heard management say they didn’t hire someone because she was fat. Very unorganized. When I was an AAM there was no clear goal to hit. You’re lied to in your interview saying in designee you’re calling on your OWN leads but in all reality you’re actually setting meetings for other account managers. The turn over rate is so high.
story: Well, as I mentioned before, I heard someone in management say that they didn’t hire someone because she was fat. I think this is absolutely disgusting because if you can hire someone with a horrible personality who was hired for their looks, then you can hire someone who was nice and would be good in sales. Also, when someone leaves Collabera, they’re basically shunned and everyone is really mean about it and unsupportive. A good part of the culture, though, is you get shouted out and recognized for any accomplishment you make - big or small.

pros: Collabera is one of the best staffing companies to work for. They always come up with something new that attracts their employees and drives them to grow themselves as well as the company.
cons:
Night shift is quite challenging as it distorts your social life. They have pretty good incentive structure but the growth from the prospect of appraisals is not at all good. I personally believe that you can't always be dependent on Incentives, appraisals are a must need and that too should not be just to a small extent. Recently made changes in the incentives structure, where recruiters are getting deduction in their incentives if they do not have hires for 2 consecutive months, is something which seems unfair as nobody is at the loss on this except for the recruiters who actually got those hires and deserve the benefit out of that. 
Also, in this Covid-19 phase, we are observing so much pressure from upper management. We have been assigned with multiple tasks that we can't dedicate our complete focus only on the recruiting part as these other tasks have been added in the KRA. It takes so much of our time that we have to extend our shifts by 1-2 hrs daily and due to this our social life is also getting distorted.
story: Collabera has always been one of the best companies known for arranging and organizing some of the best cultural activities which adds a flavor of happiness and healthy competitiveness among their employees. One such example is the MMW where employees give their 120% to achieve their targets in order to get their names on the list of tempting awards on each day of the MMW. At the same time, company believe in the physical & mental fitness of the employees and organizes sport events such as Volleyball and Cricket.

story: Collabera's culture is best exemplified by the AAM position. When you are interviewing, reading jobs descriptions, the brochures they hand out at career fairs, etc they never or very misleadingly mention the word recruiter. pros:
Collabera gives you an opportunity to work with some of the most passionate people in the industry - some of whom are really eager to service clients/consultants to the best of their abilities.
Close knitted teams, functioning together in sync.
Really excellent and knowledge people from whom you can learn.
Great Career possibilities.
Company is changing with time and trying to be at par with Digital Transformation that the world is going through.
cons:
Highly pressurized work environment.
Frequently changing work / KRA parameters.
Difference in the standards that Sales and Delivery are being held to. Pressure is too much on the Recruiters/Delivery than the sales. 
Delivery has too many parameters that they are being hold accountable for and failing in any one of them leads to taking a hit on the commission - on the same hand, sales have it very easy for them, even if they fail to meet their numbers, their commissions are not being hit.
Off-Shore/OnShore Mentality
Toned down commission plan for foreign workers.
story:
Spent my last 5 years working as a Technical Recruiter. But still was handling the entire team, straight from allocation to making sure everyone is successful. Creating and mentoring leaders - all without a title or any additional incentive.

pros: One of the best reasons for working at Collabera is the relationship building aspect - I have grown so close to my co-workers and clients that it has truly felt like a family and makes me excited to go to work every day and to help support other people and the success of their own business. There is a lot of potential for growth - professionally, financially and personally and that is the best thing that I love and am internally grateful for - this company has offered us the sky with no limit :)
cons:
as much as a work life balance is encouraged - it honestly is not. the fact that those who show success are working at least 50 hours a week and we only get the standard paid holidays  + the few days of PTO  is really discouraging. i feel like if this company recognized employees' hard work and grit by allowing more mental health days or PTO days then it would feel a little more worth it to put in the over time hours. each individual office is so completely different and has it's own culture in itself that it is even hard to comment on the culture of this company as a whole since it doesn't seem like overall as a whole corporate cares about the employees. sometimes it feels like we are just a number expected to bring in money and that every one is replaceable. sometimes it feels like there is not a whole lot of communication from corporate to each individual office - i feel like i am just working for one particular office rather than the whole company, which in a sense is true but i definitely do not feel like i belong to a company bigger than just my office. the health and wellness of employees especially during Covid/quarantine has not even been addressed - there are so many companies that have granted a few personal days here and there for the entire company to take a step back and mentally refresh from all that's going on in the world right now. even our clients have been given a Friday off here or there to take a mental day, educate themselves on what is going on in the world, debrief from the stressors and truly just take time for themselves. i have heard across the board that the hours we have been working from home are so much longer than the "standard hours" - there are days when myself and my coworkers are working until 9 or 10 at night just to wake up in a few hours to do it all over again in the same room. obviously i know you see the success from what you put into it, but sometimes it would be nice to hear from the employer that it is okay and actually encouraged every once in a while to take a step back and pause to refresh your mind body and soul so you can hit the ground running even harder after your break. we aren't given enough time off each year to take these breaks especially during the holidays when we want to spend it with our loved ones. I feel like I have to be very mindful and scarce of the time I am taking off to ensure I have time saved up throughout the year if I am sick or there is a family emergency - this wouldn't even let me live a life outside of work either. I have to be strategic and save up some time to roll over to the next year to allow myself that extra cushion in case there is an emergency or something comes up and I have to use it - we don't even have leave for bereavement. 

As much as I love this company and working for this company - it can get very overwhelming in the sense of a work/life balance not being fully respected or recognized by corporate as a whole. We don't live to work, we work to live and that needs to be celebrated and recognized so it makes it feel like our hard work and many hours spent overtime is worth it! 

Sometimes I feel like the burnout comes from the culture of the company coming across as very transaction driven rather than relational driven and it also shows from the benefits our own employees receive.
story: For being "the largest minority owned company" - it doesn't feel like it recognizes minorities. For example, during the BLM, it took quite some time for it to even be addressed and honestly as a company that employs people of all shapes, sizes and colors, it should have been addressed right away, educational resources should have been sent out, resources to talk about it with HR should have been sent out - there was a very surfaced level statement made by 1 person in this entire company and as a person of color myself, it truly didn't not seem like there was a whole lot of support given to the employees. It was so unbelievably difficult for me to wake up on that Monday morning after the passing of George Floyd and to call my clients and even talk to them about business. In the grand scheme of things, closing deals and bringing in reqs was not relevant at the time and even my close clients agreed with that so it was very hard to ask how people were doing and then to jump into a discussion about business - it was tone deaf to not even recognize what was going on and to act like it was just another day at the office. Of course, I know the world keeps on turning but sometimes when the whole world is paused and truly hurting like it has been in 2020 on an international level, there needed to be some encouragement or support to to just take a few steps back and breathe. Our company culture just pushes for numbers and transactions that we get so wrapped up in it all, we can sometimes come across as tone deaf to what is happening around us. We are a people serving business and I know that our culture should be represented each individual employee in their own way but overall our company's is saying else.

pros: I am surrounded by incredible, hard working individuals who make me want to work harder and be the best I can be.
cons: I absolutely hate the new system metal, so much so that I do all I can to use it as little as possible. Sometimes we do not have the best reputation. And lastly, I have not been able to figure out my work life balance yet due to the fear of losing my job and my boss not being able to see that I make an impact in this company in which I have talked to all of the Account Managers about as I became very down on myself and my confidence began to dwindle and it has impacted who I am as a person.
story: When I got put on a performance plan after my spread took a deep dive due to Covid and many of my hires fell through and it was one of the darkest times of my life. I was in a very negative place and mindset and was working 8 AM - 9 PM with very little reqs open but that never stopped me. The Account Managers saw immediately just how much time and hours I was putting into everything in order to simply keep my job and went out of their way to encourage me, motivate me and let me know that I am very good at my job and they do not understand how this is possible. It kept me going and pushing although it was one of the worst times I have had with the thought of "does management care about their employees because if they did they would realize how hard of a worker I am right?" or "why would I want to stay somewhere where I am not appreciated" but thanks to my coworkers they kept me strong and made me realize I am dang good at what I do and I am worth it!

pros: easy to sell delivery when you truly believe in their capabilities. Autonomy to make decisions specific to your own business/offices. Not too much corporate tape to jump through.
cons: clunky, counter-intuitive systems make day-to-day efficiency impossible. internal departments lack continuity. little to no consistency of standards/messaging. too much division of and conflict between internal departments. not enough transparancy across divisions. Often too many cooks in the kitchen. We need to have an internal phone book that maps everyone to their function so that everyone can easily keep track of who gets involved in what and where to go for questions. too many internal processes. and too many login sso, security, password issues. overkill.
story:
I love Collabera, I really do, but here is an example of the internal battles we are constantly fighting. 
We bring in a service opportunity. We sell the opportunity through several client interactions at the regional level (with the help of our regional ITSS contact, of course). We have a final presentation call set up with the client, and on the day of the call, I start getting mtg fwd notifications. suddenly 4 additional collabera people from across the country who all have NOTHING to do with this deal are accepting the invite. People are arbitrarily looping other people in on our business. I then had to spend an hour calling around and explaining why we cannot just have our entire team on a call with clients who don't know them. That is not how sales works. Everyone wants to be involved in things that don't involve them. And they want to take credit for things that they had nothing to do with. It's messy and sloppy, and does not make us look very professional. I have had several of the same experience since then. I have also dealt with some petty internal "I should be the only recruiter allowed to work on this" nonsense. Not at all helpful for the "good of the group" mentality that we should all have. unfortunately fighting these internal political nuances takes up valuable time.

cons_cleaned: clunky counter-intuitive system day-to-day efficiency impossible internal department lack continuity little consistency standard messaging division conflict internal department transparancy division cook kitchen need internal phone book map function easily track get involved question internal process login sso security password issue overkill
story_cleaned: love example internal battle constantly fighting bring service opportunity sell opportunity client interaction regional level help regional it contact course final presentation set client day start getting mtg fwd notification suddenly additional country deal accepting invite arbitrarily looping business spend hour calling explaining entire team client know sale work want involved thing involve want credit thing messy sloppy look professional experience dealt petty internal recruiter allowed nonsense helpful group mentality unfortunately fighting internal political nuance take valuable time

pros: Very Cultured Environment & Positive Leadership. Flexibility to learn & grow together. Providing platform very we can apply our skills to solve organizational & personal goals
cons:
1. As Collabera is a Recruiting & Staffing Organization, Compare to Sales & Delivery, No Strong growth & Incentive plans for GBS departments like Audit, Finance, IT. While these are most important departments and key growth driving teams. There is a lot of improvement need to be done for these teams in terms of an individual's financial growth as well as learning opportunities. 

2. There is a lot of gap between leaders & their managers. Leaders especially Team Leads/Mid-level leadership are being shadowed in many teams by managers being it by performance appraisals or recognition and shadowing their ability and visibility to higher management. Due to this, many talented & knowledgable leaders have not to be recognized which leads to an average rating of them. They are not able to perform with their full potential in spite of they are ready to take bigger roles. Managers Skip Level roles for leads will fully showcase their capability to higher management and then they should be benefited by promotions because employees in Lead roles are working with stakeholders at ground level & actually execute all the important projects with planning.   

3. There are very less flexibility benefits for Indian employees compare to US counterparts which create partiality experience for leaders between both the region. A couple of examples are different in policy for Work From Home, Flexi Benefits, different working hours, Less focus on People Health Policy, Limited Medical benefits compare to other Indian companies. These areas should be improvised   

4. Less Focused Financial Growth Plans for GBS People: Lack of Transparency in Performance Appraisals cycles. Goals defining vs Actual Roles/Responsibility performed.

cons:
It is INCREDIBLY draining to keep up with the task work- constant spreadsheets, constant updates as to where we’re at on something, every single day I probably accumulate 2-3 hours worth spent
On updating, filling things out, documentation, shared docs, etc. I work late every single day bc I prioritize my clients and recruiters and response time because I’m “staying closest to the money”. The micromanagement is at a level I’ve never experienced, and when I ask my friends in other staffing firms, their experiences are nowhere similar. It is giving me major anxiety these days and impeding on my sleep because the tasks keep coming and I can’t keep up while also conserving my mental health.
story: Two things come to mind: First, all of our incredible team/office outings. Always so fun because we work with such great people and I appreciate the “work hard, play hard” motto. Second, working as a recruiter for far longer than necessary on an account you’ve learned inside an out, being promised a territory after asking for reassurance the rug won’t be pulled out from under you, getting a promotion, and then getting moved off that account without an explanation even though everyone agreed you earned it.. aka having the rug pulled out from under you. You have to have extremely thick skin to work at Collabera, which I understand, and do.

pros: I have experienced a lot of personal development, and team building events are nice.
cons: Our hiring strategy is deeply flawed, and creates additional burden for those who successfully passed through the training program. Hiring large classes of entry level associates with 90% 12 month atrition creates a financial deficit, weakened delivery, and negative client outlook. Direct hire is directly discouraged to sell other services, as no commission is rewarded, which negatively affects revenue and morale. Culture should not be equivalent to office drama, and there is a lack of maturity from the top down. Management (top to bottom) offers little positive reinforcement, but consistently project negativity and stress on staff that drive the business.
story: Verbal, promised encentives that never materialized represent the lack of delivery and positive affirmation within Collabera. Raises, commission restructuring, incentives, etc.

pros: There is solid financial opportunity if you are willing to put in work and the time. Day to day activities provides decent variety. It's easier to sell knowing that we are providing people with work opportunities that could have a long term impact on both the contractor and their families.
cons: In the past there has seemed to be a lack of top down transparency to the distinction between Regional and Enterprise goals. The internal systems are frustrating to say the least. Commission data and tracking is entirely on the employee which is understandable but considering the lack of transparency and inconsistencies with back end data, any potential discrepancy with commission payment will be exclusively beneficial to the company which can impact trust between employees and Collabera.
story: The President Club trip certainly exemplifies the idea of work hard/play hard. After a year of hard work on everyone's part it was nice to have a pretty extravagant celebration. Also, in my entire time at Collabera, I've never seen anyone celebrate a win or hire without still having an eye towards what is coming down the pipeline in the future which shows me the level of commitment and competitive nature each successful employee has.

pros: I would describe working at Collabera as cycling through a mountain. Each climb prepares you for the next level, something that I can relate to personally.  It pushes you to the next level mentally and professionally and once you think you have reach the peak there is more to go. I have been lucky to have witness Collabera evolve to the company what is today from what it was back in 2014 and couldn't be prouder to be part of it. We provide the best solutions to our clients, and continue to be innovative and competitive. It keeps employees motivated to continue to grow their career within the company as I have in the years I've been here. Seen the SF team grow from 5 people- 3 AM, 1 recruiter, 1 CRE to a 25 person office is amazing and couldn't be prouder to have witness it. I continue to learn from my management, but also from our associates each year as they bring a new perspective to me as the office.
cons: Provide more training on new emerging technologies to seasoned account managers to keep up with the market.
story: I have so many but I will share the most recent one. I would say the story that best exemplifies Collabera's culture at this moment is my first JUMPro hire story which led to 8 additional hires throughout the first quarter of 2020. It was lot of discipline, responsive and research, passion and honestly it ended up being summed up to work hard, play hard. This was a true team effort, from pitching the idea by myself to a high level executive within bank, and involving my NAM, Director and CSO (after constant multiple meetings) we sealed the deal. It was a lot of following up, market research and maybe a glass of wine, but we landed our first JUMP hire in the account which open many doors to other account managers. It showed the client how far we would go to provided them the best talent solution in the market.

pros: Good company culture and they hire good people
cons: No 401k match, only minimum amount of holidays per year offered, I never feel like my accomplishments are enough
story:
Great people, but bad communication and processes throughout the different departments. The fact that we handle sensitive information such as SSNs, Passports, etc. over email with multiple people attached with no formal privacy training is not a good business practice. I would not want my information handled that way. 

I do like the company appreciation week, incentive trips, women's appreciation committee, etc. and the efforts made to make a good company-wide culture. However I think we need help on internal processes, communication, etc. that would make things easier. There are always too many people and departments involved with no continuity. It seems all processes make tasks harder when they could be easy.

pros: The people are why I stay at Collabera. I have had the chance to build some good relationships within the company. I feel that I am entrusted to get my work done and set my own direction on how to go about it.
cons: At times there is a sense of micromanaging or reporting for reporting sake rather than taking a realistic and efficient route to get the same kind of intel.  Doing this creates to many duplicates and wastes time. There should also be a push to have a more diverse leadership Team, especially at the director and executive level. Also, The new PTO rule where we only get two weeks and no roll over demotivates me and others greatly. I feel if we hire the right people then we should not need to restrict them from the balance they need between life and work in order to do a good job. I also believe there does need to be more flexibility after we return to the office for remote work now that we are in the new normal.
story: I think where we were and where we are headed are two very different things. Previously I think we had some good ideas and some good people but we couldn’t execute the way we should. I think previously there was a gap between leadership and the bottom line that had been ingrained into our culture. This was causing some real issues to not be addressed or truly seen by leadership enough to make necessary changes. I do think that the leadership that KK and Arun have brought in has started to shrink that gap. We need leadership that leads by example, that wants their work to be seen rather than hidden. I truly believe that we are on a better track now to get to the next level. I see how we are now truly investing in people’s training beyond the entry level. By doing so we are going to create long lasting careers for people and give them something to be proud of.
